<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">Under solvothermal conditions, a 1-D ladder polymer [Co<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:inf loc="post">1.5</ce:inf>(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) was prepared from Co(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and a dipyridyl-type ligand, <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>,<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>′-bis-pyridin-4-ylmethylene-naphthalene-1,5-diamine (<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>) in methanol. Co(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O reacted with dicarboxylic acids such as biphenyl-4,4′-dicarboxylic acid (bpdcH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>) and 2,6-naphthalene dicarboxylic acid (ndcH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>) in dma–ethanol to produce 3-D polymers, [Co<ce:inf loc="post">1.5</ce:inf>(bpdc)<ce:inf loc="post">1.5</ce:inf>(dma)]·(dma)·(EtOH) (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) and [Co<ce:inf loc="post">1.5</ce:inf>(ndc)<ce:inf loc="post">1.5</ce:inf>(dma)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>), respectively. In dmf–ethanol, another 3-D polymer [Co<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(ndc)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(dmf)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>) was prepared from Co(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and ndcH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>. Finally, a 3-D polymer [Co<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>(bpdc)]·(EtOH) (<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>), whose framework is made up of bpdc<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> and <ce:bold>L</ce:bold>, could be prepared. All polymers were structurally characterized by X-ray diffraction. Polymers <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> contain guest molecules in their frameworks.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Under solvothermal conditions, a 1-D ladder polymer [CoL 1.5(NO3)2] (1) was prepared from Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O and a dipyridyl-type ligand, N,N'-bis-pyridin-4-ylmethylene-naphthalene-1,5-diamine (L) in methanol. Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O reacted with dicarboxylic acids such as biphenyl-4,4'-dicarboxylic acid (bpdcH2) and 2,6-naphthalene dicarboxylic acid (ndcH2) in dma-ethanol to produce 3-D polymers, [Co1.5(bpdc)1.5(dma)]⋅(dma)⋅(EtOH) (2) and [Co1.5(ndc)1.5(dma)2] (3), respectively. In dmf-ethanol, another 3-D polymer [Co3(ndc)3(dmf)4] (4) was prepared from Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O and ndcH2. Finally, a 3-D polymer [CoL(bpdc)]⋅(EtOH) (5), whose framework is made up of bpdc2- and L, could be prepared. All polymers were structurally characterized by X-ray diffraction. Polymers 2 and 5 contain guest molecules in their frameworks.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Coordination polymers (or metal–organic frameworks) with various channels or cavities have useful properties applicable to catalysis, chirality, conductivity, luminescence, magnetism, adsorption, porosity, and gas storage, and therefore, they are currently under intensive study . For the preparation of these polymers, carboxylate-type ligands (linking O-donor ligands) or dipyridyl-type ligands (linking N-donor ligands) are commonly used. For example, Yaghi and co-workers have reported many intriguing coordination polymers by employing di- or multicarboxylato ligands . We have reported on the preparation of several coordination polymers based on dicarboxylates or dipyridyls under hydrothermal or solvothermal conditions .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Coordination polymers (or metal-organic frameworks) with various channels or cavities have useful properties applicable to catalysis, chirality, conductivity, luminescence, magnetism, adsorption, porosity, and gas storage, and therefore, they are currently under intensive study . For the preparation of these polymers, carboxylate-type ligands (linking O-donor ligands) or dipyridyl-type ligands (linking N-donor ligands) are commonly used. For example, Yaghi and co-workers have reported many intriguing coordination polymers by employing di- or multicarboxylato ligands . We have reported on the preparation of several coordination polymers based on dicarboxylates or dipyridyls under hydrothermal or solvothermal conditions .

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Several types of 4,4′-bipyridine derivatives are now known: 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethyne (<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>), <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic>-1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane) (<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>) , 1,4-(di-4-pyridyl)methoxy benzene (<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>) , 1,4-bis(4-pyridyl)-3,4-diaza-1,3-butadiene (<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>), 2,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-3,4-diaza-2,4-hexadiene (<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup>) , 1,4-bis(4-pyridyl)butadiyne (<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>) , <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>1-(1-(3,4-dihydropyridin-4-yl)ethylidene)-<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>2-(1-(pyridin-4-yl)ethylidene) ethane-1,2-diamine(<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">7</ce:sup>), 2-(butan-2-ylidene)-1,2-bis((pyridin-4-yl)methylene)-1,2- dihydrazine (<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">8</ce:sup>) , 2,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,3,4-thiadiazle (<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">9</ce:sup>), 2,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,3,4- oxadiazle (<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup>) , 2,2′-bis(4-pyridylmethyleneoxy)-1,1′-biphenylene (<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">11</ce:sup>) , and 1,3-bis(pyrid-4-ylthio)propane-2-one (<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>)  (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig11"></ce:float-anchor>). Among them, four ligands (<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>, <ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>, <ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">7</ce:sup>, and <ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">8</ce:sup>) were prepared by Schiff-base condensation.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Several types of 4,4'-bipyridine derivatives are now known: 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethyne (L 1), trans-1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane) (L 2) , 1,4-(di-4-pyridyl)methoxy benzene (L 3) , 1,4-bis(4-pyridyl)-3,4-diaza-1,3-butadiene (L 4), 2,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-3,4-diaza-2,4-hexadiene (L 5) , 1,4-bis(4-pyridyl)butadiyne (L 6) , N1-(1-(3,4-dihydropyridin-4-yl)ethylidene)-N2-(1-(pyridin-4-yl)ethylidene) ethane-1,2-diamine(L 7), 2-(butan-2-ylidene)-1,2-bis((pyridin-4-yl)methylene)-1,2- dihydrazine (L 8) , 2,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,3,4-thiadiazle (L 9), 2,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,3,4- oxadiazle (L 10) , 2,2'-bis(4-pyridylmethyleneoxy)-1,1'-biphenylene (L 11) , and 1,3-bis(pyrid-4-ylthio)propane-2-one (L 12)  ( ). Among them, four ligands (L 2, L 4, L 7, and L 8) were prepared by Schiff-base condensation.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Much research activity has recently been focused on the preparation of coordination polymers that contain both dicarboxylates and dipyridyls within a single framework . In preparing such polymers, dipyridyls with relatively short N⋯N distances have been employed: pyrazine , 3-(2-pyridyl)pyrazole , 1,2-di(pyridyl)ethylene , 4,4′-bipyridine , 2,2′-bipyridine , and 1,10-phenanthroline . One of our goals in this study is to introduce a novel dipyridyl-type ligand (<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>, 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig12"></ce:float-anchor>), which is quite longer than the foregoing ligands.</ce:para>

One of our goals in this study is to introduce a novel dipyridyl-type ligand (L,  ), which is quite longer than the foregoing ligands.

elements.clean_text: As a continuation of our research, we prepared novel cobalt(II) coordination polymers, [CoL 1.5(NO3)2] (1), [Co1.5(bpdc)1.5(dma)]⋅(dma)⋅(EtOH) (2), [Co1.5(ndc)1.5(dma)2] (3), [Co3(ndc)3(dmf)4] (4), and [CoL(bpdc)]⋅(EtOH) (5), from cobalt(II) nitrate, biphenyl-4,4'-dicarboxylic acid (bpdcH2), 2,6-naphthalene dicarboxylic acid (ndcH2), and a dipyridyl-type ligand (L in ) under solvothermal conditions (solvent: MeOH, EtOH, dma, or dmf). We report herein the preparation, structures, and thermal properties of these polymers.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Experimental section</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Co(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, bpdcH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, and ndcH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> were purchased and purified by recrystallization. All solvents (MeOH; EtOH; dma<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>dimethylacetamide; dmf<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>dimethylformamide) were distilled and stored over molecular sieves. Ligand <ce:bold>L</ce:bold> was prepared by the literature method . IR spectra were recorded with a Nicolet 320 FTIR spectrophotometer. Elemental analyses were performed with EA1110 (CE instrument, Italy) at the Korea Basic Science Institute. TGA analysis was conducted on a TA4000/SDT 2960 instrument at CCRF (Cooperative Center for Research Facilities) in the Sungkyunkwan University.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental section

Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O, bpdcH2, and ndcH2 were purchased and purified by recrystallization. All solvents (MeOH; EtOH; dma=dimethylacetamide; dmf=dimethylformamide) were distilled and stored over molecular sieves. Ligand L was prepared by the literature method . IR spectra were recorded with a Nicolet 320 FTIR spectrophotometer. Elemental analyses were performed with EA1110 (CE instrument, Italy) at the Korea Basic Science Institute. TGA analysis was conducted on a TA4000/SDT 2960 instrument at CCRF (Cooperative Center for Research Facilities) in the Sungkyunkwan University.

Preparation of [CoL1.5(NO3)2] (1)

In a 20ml vial, a mixture of Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.026g, 0.089mmol) and ligand L (0.043g, 0.128mmol) was dissolved in methanol (6ml). The capped vial was heated at 70°C for 24h and then air-cooled to room temperature. The red crystalline product was collected by filtration, washed with methanol (5ml×3), and then air-dried to give polymer 1 (0.035g, 0.051mmol, 57% yield). Anal. IR (KBr, cm-1): 1612 (s), 1560 (m), 1465 (s), 1383 (s), 1301 (s), 1018 (m), 790 (s).

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>X-ray structure determination</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">All X-ray data were collected with a Siemens P4 diffractometer equipped with a Mo X-ray tube. Intensity data were empirically corrected for absorption with y-scan data. All calculations were carried out with the SHELXTL programs . All crystal structures were solved by direct methods. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. All hydrogen atoms were generated in idealized positions and refined in a riding model. Details on crystal data, intensity collection, and refinement details are given in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl1"></ce:float-anchor>. Selected bond lengths and angles are given in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl2"></ce:float-anchor>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray structure determination

All X-ray data were collected with a Siemens P4 diffractometer equipped with a Mo X-ray tube. Intensity data were empirically corrected for absorption with y-scan data. All calculations were carried out with the SHELXTL programs . All crystal structures were solved by direct methods. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. All hydrogen atoms were generated in idealized positions and refined in a riding model. Details on crystal data, intensity collection, and refinement details are given in  . Selected bond lengths and angles are given in  .

elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

All polymers were prepared by solvothermal reactions and have been fully characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectroscopy, TGA, and X-ray diffraction.

Preparation and structure of 1 

The red crystalline coordination polymer [CoL 1.5(NO3)2] (1) was prepared by treating Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O and a 4,4-bipyridine-type ligand (L) in methanol at 70°C for 24h (Eq. ). The reactions above 70°C did not produce crystalline products. The IR spectrum of polymer 1 displays a CN stretch at 1612cm-1, consistent with the fact that CN stretching frequencies of Schiff bases appear in the range 1680-1603cm-1 .  (1)  Co (   NO   3     )   2   ⋅ 6   H   2   O + 1.5 L → [ Co   L   1.5   (   NO   3     )   2   ] + 6   H   2   O   Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) of polymer 1 show that its framework is stable up to 250°C. A drastic weight loss is observed from 270 to 290°C, which corresponds to the loss of two NO3 ligands and the pyridine aldehyde fragment of ligand L (observed 29%, calculated 30%), and then a subsequent weight loss gradually occurs.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">

<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor> shows the local coordination environment of cobalt in polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, in which the 6-coordinate Co(II) is bound to three pyridyl nitrogen atoms and three nitrate oxygen atoms. The monomer unit consists of one Co, one and half <ce:bold>L</ce:bold>, and two nitrato ligands (<ce:italic>η</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>-NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> and <ce:italic>η</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>-NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>), and forms a distorted octahedron. The Co<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>N and Co<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O bond lengths are 2.106(7)–2.207(6) and 2.023(8)–2.194(6)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: shows the local coordination environment of cobalt in polymer 1, in which the 6-coordinate Co(II) is bound to three pyridyl nitrogen atoms and three nitrate oxygen atoms. The monomer unit consists of one Co, one and half L, and two nitrato ligands (η 1-NO3 and η 2-NO3), and forms a distorted octahedron. The CoN and CoO bond lengths are 2.106(7)-2.207(6) and 2.023(8)-2.194(6)Å, respectively.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">

<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor> shows a projection of polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> in the [011] direction, which clearly demonstrates a ladder-like 1-D structure. Each repeating unit of the ladder consists of four cobalt atoms and four <ce:bold>L</ce:bold> ligands, creating a large 76-membered (72 ligand atoms and 4 Co metals) ring of 20.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>20.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (based on Co⋯Co separations). The N⋯N separations between two terminal pyridyl groups of ligand <ce:bold>L</ce:bold> in polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and those of the free-state ligand <ce:bold>L</ce:bold> are essentially the same (16.1 and 16.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), which indicates a high rigidity of ligand <ce:bold>L</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: shows a projection of polymer 1 in the [011] direction, which clearly demonstrates a ladder-like 1-D structure. Each repeating unit of the ladder consists of four cobalt atoms and four L ligands, creating a large 76-membered (72 ligand atoms and 4 Co metals) ring of 20.6×20.6Å (based on Co⋯Co separations). The N⋯N separations between two terminal pyridyl groups of ligand L in polymer 1 and those of the free-state ligand L are essentially the same (16.1 and 16.0Å), which indicates a high rigidity of ligand L.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">A remarkable review on the structural diversity of building blocks in coordination networks based on metal nitrate and dipyridyl ligands was recently reported by Barnett and Champness . They revealed that the different coordination modes of nitrate anions and dipyridyl functionality can result in a variety of structures, in which the pyridyl ligands can be grouped into three classes: bis(pyridyl) (<ce:bold>A</ce:bold>), tris(pyridyl) (<ce:bold>B</ce:bold>), and tetrakis(pyridyl) (<ce:bold>C</ce:bold>). The dipyridyl-type ligands (<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>) in polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> combine with the cobalt metal to form the “T-joint” units of [Co<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:inf loc="post">1.5</ce:inf>(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>], and therefore, the structural motif belongs to the class <ce:bold>B</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: A remarkable review on the structural diversity of building blocks in coordination networks based on metal nitrate and dipyridyl ligands was recently reported by Barnett and Champness . They revealed that the different coordination modes of nitrate anions and dipyridyl functionality can result in a variety of structures, in which the pyridyl ligands can be grouped into three classes: bis(pyridyl) (A), tris(pyridyl) (B), and tetrakis(pyridyl) (C). The dipyridyl-type ligands (L) in polymer 1 combine with the cobalt metal to form the "T-joint" units of [CoL 1.5(NO3)2], and therefore, the structural motif belongs to the class B.

<ce:para view="all">By employing ligands <ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup> and <ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup>, closely related to ligand <ce:bold>L</ce:bold>, a brick-wall layer polymer [Co(<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>

As mentioned in Section , we reported on the preparation of coordination polymers [Zn<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] and [Cd<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:inf loc="post">1.5</ce:inf>(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] containing ligand <ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
. The zinc coordination polymer [Zn<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] has a zigzag chain structure, whereas the cadmium coordination polymer [Cd<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:inf loc="post">1.5</ce:inf>(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] has a ladder structure with the core of the tris(pyridyl) type (<ce:bold>B</ce:bold>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: By employing ligands L 4 and L 5, closely related to ligand L, a brick-wall layer polymer [Co(L 4)1.5(NO3)2(H2O)(CH2Cl2)] and a ladder polymer [Co(L 5)2(NO3)2(C6)H6] were prepared previously . As mentioned in Section , we reported on the preparation of coordination polymers [ZnL(NO3)2] and [CdL 1.5(NO3)2] containing ligand L . The zinc coordination polymer [ZnL(NO3)2] has a zigzag chain structure, whereas the cadmium coordination polymer [CdL 1.5(NO3)2] has a ladder structure with the core of the tris(pyridyl) type (B).

</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">To introduce guest molecules, Co(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O was treated with bpdcH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> in a mixed solvent of dma and ethanol at 105<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, and the violet crystalline polymer [Co<ce:inf loc="post">1.5</ce:inf>(bpdc)<ce:inf loc="post">1.5</ce:inf>(dma)]·(dma)·(EtOH) (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) was obtained (Eq. ). TGA analysis revealed that polymer <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> loses the guest molecules (ethanol and dma) in two steps. The first weight loss occurs in the range of 100–150<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, in which the guest ethanol is lost (observed 4%, calculated 6%). The other guest molecule (dma) is gradually lost from 180 to 410<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (observed 21%, calculated 20%).<ce:display>

</ce:display>The local coordination environment of cobalt metals in polymer <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>, which exhibits two distinct cobalt atoms. One Co metal (Co1) has a trigonal bipyramidal geometry, and the other (Co2) has an octahedral geometry. The monomer unit of polymer <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> consists of 1.5 cobalt atoms, 1.5 bpdc<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands, and one dma, together with one dma and one ethanol as guest molecules. Whereas the 5-coordinate Co1 atom is bound to four oxygen atoms of three bpdc<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands and one oxygen atom of dma, the 6-coordinate Co2 is bound to six oxygen atoms of five bpdc<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands. The Co1–O5 (μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)-O type) bond (2.303<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) is significantly longer than the other Co<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O bonds (1.965(3)–2.106(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Preparation and structure of polymer 2 

To introduce guest molecules, Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O was treated with bpdcH2 in a mixed solvent of dma and ethanol at 105°C, and the violet crystalline polymer [Co1.5(bpdc)1.5(dma)]⋅(dma)⋅(EtOH) (2) was obtained (Eq. ). TGA analysis revealed that polymer 2 loses the guest molecules (ethanol and dma) in two steps. The first weight loss occurs in the range of 100-150°C, in which the guest ethanol is lost (observed 4%, calculated 6%). The other guest molecule (dma) is gradually lost from 180 to 410°C (observed 21%, calculated 20%).  (2)  Co (   NO   3     )   2   ⋅ 6   H   2   O + 1.5   bpdcH   2   ( in dma / EtOH ) → polymer  2   The local coordination environment of cobalt metals in polymer 2 is shown in  , which exhibits two distinct cobalt atoms. One Co metal (Co1) has a trigonal bipyramidal geometry, and the other (Co2) has an octahedral geometry. The monomer unit of polymer 2 consists of 1.5 cobalt atoms, 1.5 bpdc2- ligands, and one dma, together with one dma and one ethanol as guest molecules. Whereas the 5-coordinate Co1 atom is bound to four oxygen atoms of three bpdc2- ligands and one oxygen atom of dma, the 6-coordinate Co2 is bound to six oxygen atoms of five bpdc2- ligands. The Co1-O5 (μ3)-O type) bond (2.303Å) is significantly longer than the other CoO bonds (1.965(3)-2.106(3)Å).

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">

<ce:float-anchor refid="fig4"></ce:float-anchor> shows a 3-D structure of polymer <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> containing guest molecules (dma and ethanol). The bpdc<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands link the Co metals diagonally in the [011] direction to form layers and further link these layers diagonally in the [101] direction to complete a 3-D structure. We speculate that guest molecules retain their positions due to their interaction with the framework. The C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>O bond length of the coordinated (ligand) dma is 1.235(7)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and that of the guest dma is 1.300(14)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The distance between the oxygen atom of the guest dma and the hydrogen atom of the bpdc<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand (C20<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H⋯O8) in the framework is 2.461<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, which strongly suggests the C<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H⋯O type hydrogen bonding.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: shows a 3-D structure of polymer 2 containing guest molecules (dma and ethanol). The bpdc2- ligands link the Co metals diagonally in the [011] direction to form layers and further link these layers diagonally in the [101] direction to complete a 3-D structure. We speculate that guest molecules retain their positions due to their interaction with the framework. The CO bond length of the coordinated (ligand) dma is 1.235(7)Å and that of the guest dma is 1.300(14)Å. The distance between the oxygen atom of the guest dma and the hydrogen atom of the bpdc2- ligand (C20H⋯O8) in the framework is 2.461Å, which strongly suggests the CH⋯O type hydrogen bonding.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Li and co-workers prepared cobalt coordination polymers, [Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Co(bpdc)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]  and [Co(bpdc)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O , from cobalt nitrate and Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>bpdc by layer diffusion methods. In particular, the coordination polymer [Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Co(bpdc)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)] has a triple-layer structure of the Na<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>Co<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>Na type and the bpdc<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands link the layers. These results show that coordination polymers constructed from the same set of metal and ligand (bpdc<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup>) may have distinct structures depending on the preparation method and solvents used. In a similar way to the preparation of polymer <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, a zinc coordination polymer [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bpdc)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·(def)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>·(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> was prepared from zinc(II) nitrate, bpdc, diethyformamide (def), CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, dmf, and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Li and co-workers prepared cobalt coordination polymers, [Na2Co(bpdc)2(H2O)]  and [Co(bpdc)(H2O)2]⋅H2O , from cobalt nitrate and Na2bpdc by layer diffusion methods. In particular, the coordination polymer [Na2Co(bpdc)2(H2O)] has a triple-layer structure of the NaCoNa type and the bpdc2- ligands link the layers. These results show that coordination polymers constructed from the same set of metal and ligand (bpdc2-) may have distinct structures depending on the preparation method and solvents used. In a similar way to the preparation of polymer 2, a zinc coordination polymer [Zn3(OH)2(bpdc)2]⋅(def)4⋅(H2O)2 was prepared from zinc(II) nitrate, bpdc, diethyformamide (def), CH3NH2, dmf, and H2O .

<ce:float-anchor refid="fig5"></ce:float-anchor>. Unlike polymer <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, this polymer has 2 octahedral Co metals that are crystallographically distinct. The Co1 atom is bound to 6 oxygen atoms of 6 ndc<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands. On the other hand, the Co2 atom is bonded to four oxygen atoms of 3 ndc<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands and 2 oxygen atoms of 2 dma ligands. It is worth noting that all three CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> groups coordinate in different modes, and 1 carboxylate oxygen atom (O5) links the Co1 and Co2 atoms. The Co<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O bond lengths are 2.026(4)–2.173(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Preparation and structure of polymer 3 

Polymer 3 was prepared in a similarly way to polymer 2. A mixture of Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O and 2,6-ndcH2 in dma-ethanol at 105°C for 5 days produced the violet crystalline polymer [Co1.5(ndc)1.5(dma)2] (3) (Eq. ).  (3)  Co (   NO   3     )   2   ⋅ 6   H   2   O + 1.5   ndcH   2   ( in dma / EtOH ) → polymer  3   The local coordination environment of cobalt metals in polymer 3 is shown  . Unlike polymer 2, this polymer has 2 octahedral Co metals that are crystallographically distinct. The Co1 atom is bound to 6 oxygen atoms of 6 ndc2- ligands. On the other hand, the Co2 atom is bonded to four oxygen atoms of 3 ndc2- ligands and 2 oxygen atoms of 2 dma ligands. It is worth noting that all three CO2 - groups coordinate in different modes, and 1 carboxylate oxygen atom (O5) links the Co1 and Co2 atoms. The CoO bond lengths are 2.026(4)-2.173(4)Å.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">

<ce:float-anchor refid="fig6"></ce:float-anchor> shows a projection of polymer <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> along the <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>-axis, in which the ndc<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands link the Co metals diagonally in the [011] direction to form layers that are further linked in the [001] direction to form a compact 3-D structure. The dma ligands are directed toward the 3-D pore. We speculate that if the dma ligands were not present, the guest molecules could reside in the pore. It should be mentioned that many coordination polymers based on the ndc<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands were recently prepared .</ce:para>

It should be mentioned that many coordination polymers based on the ndc2- ligands were recently prepared .

elements.clean_text:
Preparation and structure of polymer 4 

Unlike polymers 2 and 3, the violet crystalline polymer 4, [Co3(ndc)3(dmf)4] (or [Co1.5(ndc)1.5(dmf)2]), was prepared by using dmf in place of dma (Eq. ).  (4)  Co (   NO   3     )   2   ⋅ 6   H   2   O +   ndcH   2    ( in dmf / EtOH ) → polymer  4      demonstrates the local coordination environment of cobalt atoms in polymer 4. Crystal structures of 3 and 4 are isostructural. The dma ligands in polymer 3 correspond to the dmf ligands in polymer 4. Like the monomer unit of polymer 3, the monomer unit of polymer 4 consists of 1.5 cobalt atoms, 1.5 ndc2- ligands, and two dmf ligands. Furthermore, two octahedral cobalt metals are distinct. A projection along the a-axis demonstrates the 3-D structure of polymer 4 ( ), which is essentially the same as that found for polymer 3.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Preparation and structure of polymer 5</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">As mentioned in Section , much research is recently focused on the preparation of coordination polymers containing a mixed-linker system, a combination of carboxylates and pyridyls, within a single framework . In preparing such polymers, relatively short dipyridyl ligands, such as pyrazine, 3-(2-pyridyl)pyrazole, 1,2-di(pyridyl)ethylene, 4,4′-bipyridine, 2,2′-bipyridine, and 1,10-phenanthroline, have been employed. We decided to prepare a novel coordination polymer that contains a long dipyridyl-type ligand <ce:bold>L</ce:bold> and a dicarboxylate. The brown crystalline polymer <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> [Co<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>(bpdc)]·(EtOH) was prepared from Co(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, bpdcH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and ligand <ce:bold>L</ce:bold> in dmf–EtOH (Eq. ). Unfortunately, the corresponding polymer containing ligand <ce:bold>L</ce:bold> and the ndc<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand could not be prepared. To our best knowledge, polymer <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> contains the longest dipyridyl ligand (<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>) among the polymers containing such a mixed ligand system. The IR spectrum of polymer <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> displays absorption bands at 1666, 1526, and 3378<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> assignable to the C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>N group, carboxyl group, and hydroxyl group (ethanol), respectively. According to the TGA analysis, polymer <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> loses guest ethanol molecules from 85 to 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (observed 5%, calculated 6%). Unfortunately, polymer <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> is formed with noncrystalline power, and therefore, its phase is not pure, although the values of elemental analyses for this polymer are satisfactory.<ce:display>
<ce:formula id="fd5">
<ce:label>(5)</ce:label>
<mml:math altimg="si5.gif" overflow="scroll">

<ce:float-anchor refid="fig9"></ce:float-anchor> shows the local coordination of the cobalt metal in polymer <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>. The coordination sphere of cobalt can be described as a pseudo-octahedron, which consists of four oxygen atoms of three bpdc<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands and two nitrogen atoms of two <ce:bold>L</ce:bold> ligands. The monomer unit of polymer <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> consists of one Co atom, one bpdc<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand, one <ce:bold>L</ce:bold> ligand, and one ethanol molecule (guest). Two carboxyl groups on the ligand bpdc<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> act as differently: one acts as a chelating group and the other as a bis(monodenate) group. The Co<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>N bond lengths are 2.174(6)–2.175(6)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, and the Co–O bond lengths are 2.001(5)–2.240(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Preparation and structure of polymer 5

As mentioned in Section , much research is recently focused on the preparation of coordination polymers containing a mixed-linker system, a combination of carboxylates and pyridyls, within a single framework . In preparing such polymers, relatively short dipyridyl ligands, such as pyrazine, 3-(2-pyridyl)pyrazole, 1,2-di(pyridyl)ethylene, 4,4'-bipyridine, 2,2'-bipyridine, and 1,10-phenanthroline, have been employed. We decided to prepare a novel coordination polymer that contains a long dipyridyl-type ligand L and a dicarboxylate. The brown crystalline polymer 5 [CoL(bpdc)]⋅(EtOH) was prepared from Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O, bpdcH2 and ligand L in dmf-EtOH (Eq. ). Unfortunately, the corresponding polymer containing ligand L and the ndc2- ligand could not be prepared. To our best knowledge, polymer 5 contains the longest dipyridyl ligand (L) among the polymers containing such a mixed ligand system. The IR spectrum of polymer 5 displays absorption bands at 1666, 1526, and 3378cm-1 assignable to the CN group, carboxyl group, and hydroxyl group (ethanol), respectively. According to the TGA analysis, polymer 5 loses guest ethanol molecules from 85 to 100°C (observed 5%, calculated 6%). Unfortunately, polymer 5 is formed with noncrystalline power, and therefore, its phase is not pure, although the values of elemental analyses for this polymer are satisfactory.  (5)  Co (   NO   3     )   2   ⋅ 6   H   2   O +   bpdcH   2   + L ( in dmf / EtOH ) → polymer  5      shows the local coordination of the cobalt metal in polymer 5. The coordination sphere of cobalt can be described as a pseudo-octahedron, which consists of four oxygen atoms of three bpdc2- ligands and two nitrogen atoms of two L ligands. The monomer unit of polymer 5 consists of one Co atom, one bpdc2- ligand, one L ligand, and one ethanol molecule (guest). Two carboxyl groups on the ligand bpdc2- act as differently: one acts as a chelating group and the other as a bis(monodenate) group. The CoN bond lengths are 2.174(6)-2.175(6)Å, and the Co-O bond lengths are 2.001(5)-2.240(5)Å.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">A projection of polymer <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> along the <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>-axis demonstrates its 3-D structure (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig10"></ce:float-anchor>a), which contains guest ethanol molecules. Two-dimensional layers are formed by the bridging bpdc<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands linking Co metals in the [011] direction, whose repeating unit consists of 4 Co metals and four <ce:bold>L</ce:bold> ligands to create a 52-membered ring (4 Co atom and 48 bpdc<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> atoms) with dimensions of 15.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>14.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å based on Co⋯Co separations (b). These layers are packed along the <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>-axis to complete a 3-D framework, in which the N⋯N separation between the two-pyridyl groups in <ce:bold>L</ce:bold> is 16.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: A projection of polymer 5 along the a-axis demonstrates its 3-D structure ( a), which contains guest ethanol molecules. Two-dimensional layers are formed by the bridging bpdc2- ligands linking Co metals in the [011] direction, whose repeating unit consists of 4 Co metals and four L ligands to create a 52-membered ring (4 Co atom and 48 bpdc2- atoms) with dimensions of 15.2×14.6Å based on Co⋯Co separations (b). These layers are packed along the a-axis to complete a 3-D framework, in which the N⋯N separation between the two-pyridyl groups in L is 16.1Å.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">In summary, five novel cobalt coordination polymers, [CoL<ce:inf loc="post">1.5</ce:inf>(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), [Co<ce:inf loc="post">1.5</ce:inf>(bpdc)<ce:inf loc="post">1.5</ce:inf>(dma)]·(dma)·(EtOH) (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), [Co<ce:inf loc="post">1.5</ce:inf>(ndc)<ce:inf loc="post">1.5</ce:inf>(dma)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>), [Co<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(ndc)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(dmf)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>), and [CoL(bpdc)]·(EtOH) (<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>), were prepared by solvothermal reactions. All polymers were structurally characterized by X-ray diffraction. Polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> has a 1-D ladder structure, and the others (polymers <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>) have a 3-D structure. In particular, the framework of polymer <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> is made up of both a dicarboxylate (bpdc) and a dipyridyl ligand (<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>). Polymers <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> contain guest molecules in their frameworks.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In summary, five novel cobalt coordination polymers, [CoL1.5(NO3)2] (1), [Co1.5(bpdc)1.5(dma)]⋅(dma)⋅(EtOH) (2), [Co1.5(ndc)1.5(dma)2] (3), [Co3(ndc)3(dmf)4] (4), and [CoL(bpdc)]⋅(EtOH) (5), were prepared by solvothermal reactions. All polymers were structurally characterized by X-ray diffraction. Polymer 1 has a 1-D ladder structure, and the others (polymers 2-4) have a 3-D structure. In particular, the framework of polymer 5 is made up of both a dicarboxylate (bpdc) and a dipyridyl ligand (L). Polymers 2 and 5 contain guest molecules in their frameworks.

On the other hand, the Co2 atom is bonded to four oxygen atoms of 3 ndc<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands and 2 oxygen atoms of 2 dma ligands. <ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> groups coordinate in different modes, and 1 carboxylate oxygen atom (O5) links the Co1 and Co2 atoms. The Co<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O bond lengths are 2.026(4)–2.173(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å.</ce:para><ce:section-title>Preparation and structure of polymer 5</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">As mentioned in Section , much research is recently focused on the preparation of coordination polymers containing a mixed-linker system, a combination of carboxylates and pyridyls, within a single framework . In preparing such polymers, relatively short dipyridyl ligands, such as pyrazine, 3-(2-pyridyl)pyrazole, 1,2-di(pyridyl)ethylene, 4,4′-bipyridine, 2,2′-bipyridine, and 1,10-phenanthroline, have been employed. We decided to prepare a novel coordination polymer that contains a long dipyridyl-type ligand <ce:bold>L</ce:bold> and a dicarboxylate. The brown crystalline polymer <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> [Co<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>(bpdc)]·(EtOH) was prepared from Co(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, bpdcH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and ligand <ce:bold>L</ce:bold> in dmf–EtOH (Eq. ). Unfortunately, the corresponding polymer containing ligand <ce:bold>L</ce:bold> and the ndc<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand could not be prepared. To our best knowledge, polymer <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> contains the longest dipyridyl ligand (<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>) among the polymers containing such a mixed ligand system. The IR spectrum of polymer <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> displays absorption bands at 1666, 1526, and 3378<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> assignable to the C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>N group, carboxyl group, and hydroxyl group (ethanol), respectively. According to the TGA analysis, polymer <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> loses guest ethanol molecules from 85 to 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (observed 5%, calculated 6%). Unfortunately, polymer <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> is formed with noncrystalline power, and therefore, its phase is not pure, although the values of elemental analyses for this polymer are satisfactory.<ce:display>

<ce:float-anchor refid="fig9"></ce:float-anchor> shows the local coordination of the cobalt metal in polymer <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>. The coordination sphere of cobalt can be described as a pseudo-octahedron, which consists of four oxygen atoms of three bpdc<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands and two nitrogen atoms of two <ce:bold>L</ce:bold> ligands. The monomer unit of polymer <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> consists of one Co atom, one bpdc<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand, one <ce:bold>L</ce:bold> ligand, and one ethanol molecule (guest). Two carboxyl groups on the ligand bpdc<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> act as differently: one acts as a chelating group and the other as a bis(monodenate) group. The Co<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>N bond lengths are 2.174(6)–2.175(6)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, and the Co–O bond lengths are 2.001(5)–2.240(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
Preparation of [CoL1.5(NO3)2] (1)

In a 20ml vial, a mixture of Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.026g, 0.089mmol) and ligand L (0.043g, 0.128mmol) was dissolved in methanol (6ml). The capped vial was heated at 70°C for 24h and then air-cooled to room temperature. The red crystalline product was collected by filtration, washed with methanol (5ml×3), and then air-dried to give polymer 1 (0.035g, 0.051mmol, 57% yield). Anal. Calcd for C33H24N8O6Co M r =687.53: C, 57.65; H, 3.52; N, 16.30. Found: C, 57.44; H, 3.82; N, 16.10. mp (decomp): 248-250°C. IR (KBr, cm-1): 1612 (s), 1560 (m), 1465 (s), 1383 (s), 1301 (s), 1018 (m), 790 (s).

Preparation of [Co1.5(bpdc)1.5(dma)]⋅(dma)⋅(EtOH) (2)

A mixture of Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.028g, 0.096mmol) and 4,4'-bpdcH2 (0.023g, 0.095mmol) was dissolved in dma-ethanol (2:1 by volume, 9ml). The resulting solution was allowed to stand in the oven at 105°C for three days, and then air-cooled to room temperature. The violet crystalline product was collected by filtration, and then washed with dma (5ml×2) and ethanol (5ml×3) to give polymer 2 (0.039g, 0.058mmol, 61%). Anal. Calcd for C31H36N2O9Co1.5 (M r =669.01): C, 55.65; H, 5.42; N, 4.19. Found: C, 55.61; H, 5.33; N, 4.08. mp (decomp): 274-276°C. IR (KBr, cm-1: 3378 (w), 1685 (m), 1577 (s), 1528 (s), 1503 (s), 1412 (s), 838 (m), 770 (m).

Preparation of [Co1.5(ndc)1.5(dma)2] (3)

Polymer 3 was prepared in the same way as polymer 2. A mixture of Co(NO3)2)⋅6H2O (0.025g, 0086mmol), 2,6-ndcH2 (0.019g, 0.088mmol), dma (6ml), and ethanol (3ml) was heated to produce the violet crystalline polymer 3 (0.061g, 0.048mmol, 60%). Anal. Calcd for C26H27N2O8Co1.5 (M r =583.89): C, 53.48; H, 4.66; N, 4.80. Found: C, 53.66; H, 4.48; N, 4.78. mp (decomp): 204-206°C. IR (KBr, cm-1: 1548 (m), 1395 (s), 1192 (m), 944 (w), 779 (s), 577 (w), 410 (s).

Preparation of [Co3(ndc)3(dmf)4] (4)

Polymer 4 was also prepared in the same way as polymer 2. A mixture of Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.030g, 0.104mmol), 2,6-ndcH2, (0.024g, 0.111mmol), dmf (6ml), and ethanol (3ml) was heated to give the violet crystalline polymer 4 (0.053g, 0.048mmol, 69%). Anal. Calcd for C48H46N4O16Co3 (M r =1111.68): C, 51.86; H, 5.42; N, 4.19. Found: C, 51.61; H, 5.17; N, 5.04. mp (decomp): 198-200°C. IR (KBr, cm-1): 1550 (s), 1399 (s), 1193 (w), 947 (w), 792 (s), 642 (m), 472 (m).

Preparation of [CoL(bpdc)]⋅(EtOH) (5)

Polymer 5 was also prepared in the same way as polymer 2. Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.027g, 0.092mmol), ligand L (0.030g, 0.104mmol), 4,4'-bpdcH2 (0.021g, 0.087mmol), dmf (6ml), and ethanol (3ml) were heated to give brown crystalline polymer 5 as well as some noncrystalline powder (0.041g, 0.060 mmol, 73%). Anal. Calcd for C38H30N4O5Co (M r =681.59): C, 66.96; H, 4.45; N, 8.22. Found: C, 66.18; H, 4.51; N, 8.12. mp (decomp): 236-238°C. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3439 (w), 1777 (m), 1666 (m), 1609 (s), 1410 (s), 777 (s), 673 (m).

Preparation and structure of polymer 2 

To introduce guest molecules, Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O was treated with bpdcH2 in a mixed solvent of dma and ethanol at 105°C, and the violet crystalline polymer [Co1.5(bpdc)1.5(dma)]⋅(dma)⋅(EtOH) (2) was obtained (Eq. ). TGA analysis revealed that polymer 2 loses the guest molecules (ethanol and dma) in two steps. The first weight loss occurs in the range of 100-150°C, in which the guest ethanol is lost (observed 4%, calculated 6%). The other guest molecule (dma) is gradually lost from 180 to 410°C (observed 21%, calculated 20%).  (2)  Co (   NO   3     )   2   ⋅ 6   H   2   O + 1.5   bpdcH   2   ( in dma / EtOH ) → polymer  2   The local coordination environment of cobalt metals in polymer 2 is shown in  , which exhibits two distinct cobalt atoms. One Co metal (Co1) has a trigonal bipyramidal geometry, and the other (Co2) has an octahedral geometry. The monomer unit of polymer 2 consists of 1.5 cobalt atoms, 1.5 bpdc2- ligands, and one dma, together with one dma and one ethanol as guest molecules. Whereas the 5-coordinate Co1 atom is bound to four oxygen atoms of three bpdc2- ligands and one oxygen atom of dma, the 6-coordinate Co2 is bound to six oxygen atoms of five bpdc2- ligands. The Co1-O5 (μ3)-O type) bond (2.303Å) is significantly longer than the other CoO bonds (1.965(3)-2.106(3)Å).

Preparation and structure of polymer 3 

Polymer 3 was prepared in a similarly way to polymer 2. A mixture of Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O and 2,6-ndcH2 in dma-ethanol at 105°C for 5 days produced the violet crystalline polymer [Co1.5(ndc)1.5(dma)2] (3) (Eq. ).  (3)  Co (   NO   3     )   2   ⋅ 6   H   2   O + 1.5   ndcH   2   ( in dma / EtOH ) → polymer  3   The local coordination environment of cobalt metals in polymer 3 is shown  . Unlike polymer 2, this polymer has 2 octahedral Co metals that are crystallographically distinct. The Co1 atom is bound to 6 oxygen atoms of 6 ndc2- ligands. On the other hand, the Co2 atom is bonded to four oxygen atoms of 3 ndc2- ligands and 2 oxygen atoms of 2 dma ligands. It is worth noting that all three CO2 - groups coordinate in different modes, and 1 carboxylate oxygen atom (O5) links the Co1 and Co2 atoms. The CoO bond lengths are 2.026(4)-2.173(4)Å.

Preparation and structure of polymer 5

As mentioned in Section , much research is recently focused on the preparation of coordination polymers containing a mixed-linker system, a combination of carboxylates and pyridyls, within a single framework . In preparing such polymers, relatively short dipyridyl ligands, such as pyrazine, 3-(2-pyridyl)pyrazole, 1,2-di(pyridyl)ethylene, 4,4'-bipyridine, 2,2'-bipyridine, and 1,10-phenanthroline, have been employed. We decided to prepare a novel coordination polymer that contains a long dipyridyl-type ligand L and a dicarboxylate. The brown crystalline polymer 5 [CoL(bpdc)]⋅(EtOH) was prepared from Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O, bpdcH2 and ligand L in dmf-EtOH (Eq. ). Unfortunately, the corresponding polymer containing ligand L and the ndc2- ligand could not be prepared. To our best knowledge, polymer 5 contains the longest dipyridyl ligand (L) among the polymers containing such a mixed ligand system. The IR spectrum of polymer 5 displays absorption bands at 1666, 1526, and 3378cm-1 assignable to the CN group, carboxyl group, and hydroxyl group (ethanol), respectively. According to the TGA analysis, polymer 5 loses guest ethanol molecules from 85 to 100°C (observed 5%, calculated 6%). Unfortunately, polymer 5 is formed with noncrystalline power, and therefore, its phase is not pure, although the values of elemental analyses for this polymer are satisfactory.  (5)  Co (   NO   3     )   2   ⋅ 6   H   2   O +   bpdcH   2   + L ( in dmf / EtOH ) → polymer  5      shows the local coordination of the cobalt metal in polymer 5. The coordination sphere of cobalt can be described as a pseudo-octahedron, which consists of four oxygen atoms of three bpdc2- ligands and two nitrogen atoms of two L ligands. The monomer unit of polymer 5 consists of one Co atom, one bpdc2- ligand, one L ligand, and one ethanol molecule (guest). Two carboxyl groups on the ligand bpdc2- act as differently: one acts as a chelating group and the other as a bis(monodenate) group. The CoN bond lengths are 2.174(6)-2.175(6)Å, and the Co-O bond lengths are 2.001(5)-2.240(5)Å.

Results and discussion

All polymers were prepared by solvothermal reactions and have been fully characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectroscopy, TGA, and X-ray diffraction.

Preparation and structure of 1 

The red crystalline coordination polymer [CoL 1.5(NO3)2] (1) was prepared by treating Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O and a 4,4-bipyridine-type ligand (L) in methanol at 70°C for 24h (Eq. ). The reactions above 70°C did not produce crystalline products. The IR spectrum of polymer 1 displays a CN stretch at 1612cm-1, consistent with the fact that CN stretching frequencies of Schiff bases appear in the range 1680-1603cm-1 .  (1)  Co (   NO   3     )   2   ⋅ 6   H   2   O + 1.5 L → [ Co   L   1.5   (   NO   3     )   2   ] + 6   H   2   O   Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) of polymer 1 show that its framework is stable up to 250°C. A drastic weight loss is observed from 270 to 290°C, which corresponds to the loss of two NO3 ligands and the pyridine aldehyde fragment of ligand L (observed 29%, calculated 30%), and then a subsequent weight loss gradually occurs.

   shows a projection of polymer 1 in the [011] direction, which clearly demonstrates a ladder-like 1-D structure. Each repeating unit of the ladder consists of four cobalt atoms and four L ligands, creating a large 76-membered (72 ligand atoms and 4 Co metals) ring of 20.6×20.6Å (based on Co⋯Co separations). The N⋯N separations between two terminal pyridyl groups of ligand L in polymer 1 and those of the free-state ligand L are essentially the same (16.1 and 16.0Å), which indicates a high rigidity of ligand L.

A projection of polymer 5 along the a-axis demonstrates its 3-D structure ( a), which contains guest ethanol molecules. Two-dimensional layers are formed by the bridging bpdc2- ligands linking Co metals in the [011] direction, whose repeating unit consists of 4 Co metals and four L ligands to create a 52-membered ring (4 Co atom and 48 bpdc2- atoms) with dimensions of 15.2×14.6Å based on Co⋯Co separations (b). These layers are packed along the a-axis to complete a 3-D framework, in which the N⋯N separation between the two-pyridyl groups in L is 16.1Å.
